job_description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution. DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees. We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day.     The Supervisor Watershed Maintenance-II, working in the Division of Reservoir Operations, will oversee the work of all Level I Supervisors and their subordinates in the maintenance and operation of chemical feed systems and related equipment. Working under the direction of the Risk Program Manager, he/she may oversee both field and office maintenance activities related to the Risk Management Program.This is a supervisory class of positions which entails providing direction to staff involved in the operation, maintenance, repair and inspection of facilities, roads, bridges, equipment and lands in the watershed areas including reservoirs, aqueducts, groundwater, water and waste water treatment and related systems of the City of New York. The Supervisor Watershed Maintenance-II ensures all work performed is in compliance with applicable federal, state, local and Agency environmental health and safety laws, policies and procedures. All personnel perform related work and may perform the duties of subordinates assignment Level.
minimum_qual_requirements: A four-year high school diploma or its educational equivalent, plus three years of recent satisfactory experience in the operation, maintenance, repair, construction or inspection of facilities, equipment and lands in a watershed area, including aqueducts, reservoirs, water and/or waste water treatment plants; at least one year of which must have been in a supervisory capacity.    For Assignment Level II  In addition to meeting the ''Qualification Requirements'' above, to be assigned to Assignment Level II, candidates must have one additional year of full-time satisfactory experience in a supervisory capacity, as described above, for a total of four years of experience.    For Assignment Level III  In addition to meeting the ''Qualification Requirements'' above, to be assigned to Assignment Level III, candidates must have four additional years of full-time satisfactory experience, as described above, at least two of which must have been in a supervisory capacity, for a total of seven years of experience.    License Requirement  A Motor Vehicle Driver License valid in the State of New York. This license must be maintained for the duration of employment.
additional_information: Appointments are subject to OMB Approval.  For additional information about DEP, Visit www.nyc.gov/dep    License Requirements- Must possess and maintain a Grade 2B Water Treatment Operator License.

job_description: Reporting to the Senior Director for Operations, the successful candidate will serve as the leading financial entrepreneur focused on NYCHA's preservation and development of affordable housing across NYCHA's portfolio.  Specific duties shall include, but not be limited to the following:    1.  Identify NYCHA portfolio opportunities for both equity and debt investments focused on preservation and affordable housing.  2.  Evaluate transactions for credit risk  3.  Serve on the senior management team; oversee team of underwriters and financial analysts.  4.  Structure investments in HUD mixed-finance preservation and affordable housing projects.  5.  Prepare and present debt and equity investment proposals including a comprehensive income and expense analysis, market feasibility, sensitivity analysis.  6.  Review and evaluate due diligence materials including existing conditions reports, third party reports, operating statements, rent rolls, loan documents, affordability regulatory agreements, ground leases, borrower/investor financial position.  7.  Perform extensive market research on both a regional and submarket basis.  8.  Create, update and refine financial models to reflect deal structure modifications on equity, debt investments, as needed.  9.  Provide professional and timely customer service to NYCHA internal and external clients.  10.  Work with clients and internal staff to effectively manage multiple transactions and move projects forward.  11.  Travel to NYCHA developments to conduct property inspections.      Please read this posting carefully to make certain you meet the minimum qualification requirements before applying to this position.

Under the direction of the Deputy Commissioner, the Senior Advisor for the Early Childhood Health and Development will be responsible for the following duties:  â€¢	Support the Deputy Commissioner and Senior Leadership Team in developing and implementing effective legislative, administrative and political Early Childhood Health and Development strategies.  â€¢	Build and nurture effective relationships and partnerships with key stakeholders, including other city agencies, policymakers, state agency leads, key stakeholders and practitioners.   â€¢	Serve as a resource and thought leader in the field.   â€¢	Research issues and draft testimony, presentations, policy briefs, reports, research memos, fact sheets and other supportive materials that clearly and concisely describe complex Early Childhood Health and Development issues.   â€¢	Other duties as assigned

job_description: Please read this posting carefully to make certain you meet the qualification requirements before applying to this position.    Attorneys in the Landlord & Tenant Division of Housing Litigation represent the agency in non-payment, holdover, Section 8, Bawdy House, repair cases, and commercial cases in Housing Court.  In addition, the attorneys appear on behalf of the Authority as a creditor in Federal Bankruptcy Court.  Responsibilities shall include, but not be limited to the following:    1.  Represent NYCHA in Civil Court-Housing Part, negotiate, draft and appear before Judge for stipulations of settlement involving non-payment, holdover and repair cases.  2.  Research and prepare non-payment and holdover cases for Trial and argue them before a Housing Court Judge.  3.  Prepare briefs, motions, legal opinions, affidavits, memoranda and other legal papers.  4.  Represent and defend NYCHA in repair cases commenced by residents; negotiate stipulations of settlement, argue motions, and may proceed to trial on said repair cases; contact and advise developments and assist in access dates for the repairs.  Confer with skilled trades and technical services to ensure repairs are completed as expeditiously as possible.  5.  Appear and represent NYCHA in the position of Judgment Creditor in Bankruptcy Court; prepare and file appropriate motions to ensure all pre-petition and post-petition rent is collected by the Authority.  6.  Perform other related duties.    Admission to the New York State Bar and Federal District Court is required.    The selected candidate is required to maintain confidentiality regarding all NYCHA proceedings.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. Admission to the New York State Bar; and either ''2'' or ''3'' below.  2. One year of satisfactory United States legal experience subsequent to admission to any state bar; or   3. Six months of satisfactory service as an Agency Attorney Interne (30086).    Incumbents must remain Members of the New York State Bar in good standing for the duration of this employment.  In addition to meeting the minimum Qualification Requirements:  To be assigned to Assignment Level (AL) II, candidates must have one year of experience at Assignment Level I or two years of comparable legal experience subsequent to admission to the bar, in the areas of law related to the assignment. To be assigned to AL III candidates must have two years of experience in Assignment Levels I and/or II or three years of comparable legal experience subsequent to admission to the bar, in the areas of law related to the assignment.

job_description: The goal of HPDâ€™s Planning Division is to ensure that the agencyâ€™s investments in affordable housing leverage and incentivize other public and private investments and achieve broader community objectives that strengthen the social, economic, and physical health of neighborhoods. Situated within the Planning Division, the Predevelopment Planning team works on key strategic projects for the agency, including all Requests for Proposals and other master planning initiatives for complex development on City-owned land. The Predevelopment Planning team seeks a Planner who will report to the teamâ€™s Director and take on a variety of analytical, planning, and project management responsibilities related to the predevelopment phase of housing developments sponsored and/or financed by HPD.     Working with the Director and Senior Planner, the Planner will develop requests for proposals (RFPs) for the development of city-owned parcels and oversee the proposal review and selection process, and will be responsible for ensuring that development, design, and planning solutions meet HPD and other city policy objectives. Selected duties include project management during the development, release, and review of RFPs; analyzing, resolving, and advising on complex neighborhood planning, zoning, and land use issues; and ensuring that planning strategies are grounded in sound real estate finance and development principles.      The Planner will work collaboratively throughout the predevelopment process with Borough Planning Directors and Planners, other NYC agencies (e.g. the Economic Development Corporation, Department of City Planning, New York City Housing Authority), for- and non- profit housing and community developers, Community Boards and local organizations, public officials, and neighborhood residents. All Planners within the Office of Neighborhood Strategies are expected to participate in and assist with neighborhood workshops, as necessary, which may entail evening and occasional weekend work.

Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have at least one year of experience as described in ''1'' above.

Experience conducting studies, writing reports, and conducting meetings with community and interagency partners.      Ability to work independently, take initiative, and work effectively with others.      Excellent research, analytical, writing, and public speaking skills.      Demonstrated ability to meet deadlines and manage multiple projects in a timely manner.    Training and/or certification in project management, and proficiency in GIS, the Adobe Creative Suite, and Microsoft Office applications including PowerPoint.     Candidates with masters degrees in urban planning, urban design/architecture or business administration with a focus in real estate finance and development are strongly preferred.     A minimum 2 years experience in urban planning is strongly preferred, preferably involving the practical application of real estate principles in finance and/or development.

business_title: Project Director, Bureau of Correctional Health Services
business_title_phonetic: Project Director, Bureau of Correctional Health Services
work_location: Hazen St-West Facil, E. Elm, N
job_description: The Health Departmentâ€™s Division of Prevention and Primary Care, Bureau of Correctional Health Services-Transitional Health Care Coordination has a vacancy for a City Research Scientist II.  Transitional Health Care Coordination is responsible for overseeing health education programs and coordinating community collaborations to facilitate linkages to health care for those leaving City jails with chronic health conditions such as hypertension, diabetes and asthma as well as STDs and HIV/AIDS.  Transitional Health Care Coordination services are integrated with other programs in the Bureau of Correctional Health Services and the Bureau of Primary Care Access & Planning.  It also has partnerships with other DOHMH programs, the District Public Health Offices, other City agencies and community-based providers throughout the City.  In addition, THCC works closely with the jail based health providers to facilitate continuity of care from intake jails to community health care for those in City jails, returning to the communities of greatest health disparities, who face multiple social service issues, are unemployed or under-employed.    Under direction and supervision by the Executive Director of the Transitional Health Care Coordination program (THCC), the Project Director is responsible for designing and executing research and evaluation projects to monitor and evaluate various operational and policy initiatives launched by THCC.  These initiatives fall into a broad range of areas, included but not limited to, providing transitional health care services to persons incarcerated in NYC jails, verifying linkage to services for persons released to the community, and focused federal initiatives to enhance services.    Specific Duties and Responsibilities    â€¢	Oversee research and evaluation activities for THCC with a special focus on federal grants from the Health Resource Services Administration (HRSA), Strategic Programs of National Significance (SPNS) and the Office of Minority Health (OMH).  Conduct research/investigations as required by federal grants and as requested by Executive Director.    â€¢	Oversee data collection, analysis and day-to-day management of quantitative and qualitative research/evaluation activities for multi-site and local studies including to:    o	Develop research designs and evaluation plans to monitor and evaluate THCC initiatives, programs and policies.    o	Develop research/evaluation instruments.    o	Collect, manage and analyze data; compile and present results.    o	Develop written manuscripts and reports with findings to inform program policy, administration and for publication.     â€¢	Guide and supervise staff who support above research/evaluation activities.    â€¢	Conduct statistical analyses of research, evaluation and administrative data.    â€¢	Collaborate with program administrators and staff to integrate research/evaluation activities into program operations.    â€¢	Train appropriate jail and field based staff in obtaining informed consent, data collection and monitoring.    â€¢	Develop Institutional Review Board protocol summaries and proposals and liaise with IRB chair during approval process.    â€¢	Write sections of proposals for future funding related to research/evaluation.    â€¢	Consult with DOHMH researchers and external consultants related to research design and implementation.

job_description: Hiring Rate: $66.45 Per Hour (Flat Rate)  On-Board Rate After One Year: $71.18 Per Hour  (Flat Rate)    Healthy Start Brooklyn (HSB) is a federally funded program to reduce infant mortality, improve maternal-infant health, and reduce health disparities.  In New York City, neighborhoods in Central Brooklyn experience disproportionately high rates of infant mortality and low birth weight babies compared to other areas of the city.  HSB is a multi-year grant that supports the provision of services and the coordination of community response to address these important public health disparities.  The grant is awarded by the federal Health Resource Services Administration (HRSA) to the Fund for Public Health in New York (FPHNY) on behalf of and in partnership with the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH).    Position Overview:  The Medical Director is a part-time position, two days a week. The Medical Director (MD) will be responsible for providing a clinical perspective on the work of Healthy Start Brooklyn. In particular, the MD will be concerned with two of the five Healthy Start approaches: improving womenâ€™s health and promoting quality services. The MDâ€™s duties will include but not be limited to the following:    Administration and Service Delivery  --	Lead HSBâ€™s efforts in insurance enrollment, reproductive life planning, infant mortality, pre/inter-conception health, and other medical initiatives.'     --	Assist with Healthy Start Brooklynâ€™s placed-based efforts, including development of the Healthy Start Zone in Brownsville.    --	Collaborate on collective-impact efforts through the Community Action Network.    --	Share expertise in process, program, and evaluation with HSB mentees    Strategic Planning and Program Development   --	Build relationships with clinical providers in the HSB program area, including hospitals, clinics, OB-GYNs, pediatricians, and family physicians.    --	Develop a community-based research and strategic planning process around coordinated, sustainable systems of care.    --	Convene other city, state, and federal agencies and programs to collaborate on MCH-related initiatives affecting the grantâ€™s target populations and communities.    --	Collaborate with other divisions of the Brooklyn DPHO and the DOHMH to promote initiatives that target shared goals and objectives.    --	Represent HSB at federal, state, city, and local events and meetings.    --	Participate in the development and implementation of the Healthy Start Institute, standard curriculum, and Collaboration and Innovation Improvement Network (CoIIN).    Evaluation and Quality Assurance   --	Conduct community research initiatives around the topic of maternal and child health, with the purpose of informing the program activities and the community at large

job_description: The Finance Information Technology Division delivers world-class information and technology solutions that the agency needs to achieve results. The Division is seeking an individual who will work independently as a Tivoli Workload Scheduler.    The duties for the selected candidate will include, but are not limited to, the following:     - Create technical approach for production batch scheduling of multiple distributed applications   - Coordinate batch-scheduling needs.   - Identify technical, infrastructure and procedural issues related to batch scheduling.   - Assist in operations architecture, including event monitoring.
minimum_qual_requirements: (1) A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college, including or supplemented by twenty-four (24) semester credits in computer science or a related computer field and two (2) years of satisfactory full-time software experience in designing, programming, debugging, maintaining, implementing, and enhancing computer software applications, systems programming, systems analysis and design, data communication software, or database design and programming, including one year in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project; or  (2) A four-year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and six (6) years of full-time satisfactory software experience as described in â€œ1'' above, including one year in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project; or  (3) A satisfactory combination of education and experience that is equivalent to (1) or (2) above. College education may be substituted for up to two years of the required experience in (2) above on the basis that sixty (60) semester credits from an accredited college is equated to one year of experience. A masters degree in computer science or a related computer field may be substituted for one year of the required experience in (1) or (2) above. However, all candidates must have a four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent, plus at least one (1) year of satisfactory full-time software experience in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project.  NOTE: In order to have your experience accepted as Project Leader or Major Contributor experience, you must explain in detail how your experience qualifies you as a project leader or as a major contributor. Special Note  To be eligible for placement in Assignment Level IV, in addition to the Qualification Requirements stated above, individuals must have one year of satisfactory experience in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project in data administration, database management systems, operating systems, data communications systems, capacity planning, and/or on-line applications programming.
preferred_skills: Candidates should have:      - Experience in  a distributed systems environment (Windows and Unix/Linux, Mainframe a Plus).    - Experience in creating and maintaining operational run books for distributed batch operations   - Experience with Tivoli Workload Scheduler or similar job scheduling software in a distributed      environment   - Experience with root cause analysis (researching application error logs) and basic problem solving skills   - Experience with shell scripting a plus

job_description: JOB DESCRIPTION:    The New York City Department of Youth and Community Development (DYCD) supports youth and community services through contracts with community-based organizations (CBOs). DYCDâ€™s central task is to administer available city, state, and federal funds to a wide range of quality programs that positively impact youth and communities.     DYCDâ€™s Comprehensive Afterschool System of NYC (COMPASS), formerly known as the Out-of-School Time (OST) Program, is the agencyâ€™s largest initiative and currently serves over 85,000 young people in more than 800 programs across the five boroughs.  COMPASS programs take place after school, during school closing days and over the summer.  High quality learning opportunities offer a balance of academics, recreation, enrichment, and cultural activities to help kids succeed in and out of school.      DYCDâ€™s COMPASS unit strategically supports CBOs that directly operate programs through funding, monitoring, coaching, capacity building, evaluation and advocacy.  DYCD is seeking an Instruction and Learning Strategist who will be responsible for providing strategic planning for the COMPASS system in the area of in- and out-of-school learning.  This position is part of the Program Quality and Innovations team, a new division within the COMPASS unit, designed to enhance the COMPASS systemâ€™s program performance by (1) identifying best practices, new pilots and resources, (2) developing new tools and materials to support and evaluate program performance and services, and (3) helping to create professional development training tracks for COMPASS staff and COMPASS providers.  The Instruction and Learning Strategist will be on the COMPASS management team.  Some specific duties will include:     â€¢Identify and promote formal and informal learning approaches that are appropriate to after school and out-of-school time settings for the systemâ€™s 800 K-12 programs.    â€¢Design collaboration strategies for COMPASS programs located in Department of Education school buildings to support the interests and needs of multiple stakeholders.    â€¢Impact a broad level of instructional approaches in after school using Project-Based Learning, Common Core Standards, experiential learning, and other teaching and learning approaches.     â€¢Identify curricula supports to strengthen COMPASS enrichment areas, especially STEM, Literacy, Arts, and Leadership Development.    â€¢Provide professional development and work in small-group facilitation with the COMPASS team.    â€¢Establish learning communities that support quality programming for community-based agency staff, including on-site Program Directors responsible for programs serving 90-120 students; Educational Specialists responsible for COMPASS programâ€™s lesson planning, curriculum development, and activity implementation; and school teachers, teaching artists, coaches, and principals.    â€¢Document and disseminate best practices.     â€¢Help programs create program-based professional development plans.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and four years of full-time, satisfactory professional, technical or administrative experience in one or more of the following fields: program evaluation, contract negotiations/management, business or public administration, contract community relations, or related fields; at least eighteen months must have been in an administrative, managerial or executive capacity, or supervising professional personnel performing work in program evaluation, contract negotiation/management, business or public administration; or  2. A four year high school diploma, or its equivalent, and six years of full-time, professional, technical or administrative work experience in one or more of the fields cited above; at least eighteen months must have been in an administrative, managerial or executive capacity, or supervising professional personnel as described in ''1'' above; or  3. A satisfactory equivalent of education and experience as cited above. However, all candidates must have the eighteen months of administrative, managerial or executive experience or experience supervising professional personnel as described in ''1'' above.
preferred_skills: 1. Bachelorâ€™s degree with at least five years of experience in the field of education in formal and/or informal settings, teaching and learning, and/or instructional support.    2. Experience in K-8 classroom teaching in a formal or informal setting with demonstrated experience in supporting students through instructional, administrative, and or programmatic methods  .  3. Experience in Project-Based Learning, Experiential learning, among other approaches.     4. Working knowledge of the Common Core standards and methodologies for implementation across various content areas.    5. Expertise in training and staff development practices to improve achievement, especially with diverse staffing patterns in underserved communities.     6. Knowledge of adolescent programming needs a plus.     7. Familiar with outcome assessment.    8. Demonstrated knowledge of data analysis and using data to drive instruction and measure student achievement.     9. Strong organizational skills and ability to manage multiple projects in a fast-paced environment.

job_description: 1.  Ensure estimates are developed and managed in the most efficient and effective manner.  2. Supervise staff.  4.  Prepare cost studies, complex research, trend estimates, life cycle cost estimates for capital project electrical and specialized areas or discipline.  5.  Prepare scope of work, design development, bid and change order phase cost estimates necessary for the planning, construction, repair of structures, or installations for electrical work and other trade discipline as required.  6.  Prepare quantity surveys and cost evaluations for contract drawings, specifications or contract changes.  7.  Ensure unit costs and quantities of materials are accurate.  8.  Establish formal and content summaries and reconciliations, including segregation of cost according to confidence level.  9.  Prepare basic software generated estimates for completion and technical accuracy ensuring quality and integrity.  10.  Prepare contingency and escalation through manual calculations.  11.  May attend bid openings.  12.  Prepare estimates for Change Order negotiation by analyzing awarded electrical contract breakdown, along with verifying itemized costs against the scopes of work and construction document packages. Review change order proposals for quantities and fair price; ensure that the costs of project stay within budget.  13.  Review and analyze contract cost estimates/delay claims prepared by external consultants for accuracy and reasonableness; perform reconciliation and make recommendations.  14.  Recommend, coordinate, and update current cost variations for the project cost trend program, price library, NYCHA historical database, and other reference material.

job_description: DoITT provides for the sustained, efficient and effective delivery of IT services, infrastructure and telecommunications to enhance service delivery to New York City's residents, businesses, employees and visitors. As the City's technology leader, DoITT is responsible for maintaining the foundational IT infrastructure and systems that touch every aspect of City life from public safety to human services, from education to economic development crossing the full spectrum of governmental operations.    The successful candidate will serve as a Principal Design Engineer reporting to the IT Services Division. Responsibilities will include: Design and implementation of Enterprise Extender for all IBM mainframe cross-domain connectivity; perform monitoring of production resources network performance; provide accurate instructions to operations and service desk staff as required to support both network operations, and level 1 problem determination, for mainframe network resources; plan and schedule network software changes as required to be implemented according to DoITT s change policies and available maintenance windows;; create and modify communication server for z/OS software configurations on all LPARs as required, for both SNA and TCP/IP protocols under the direction of senior technical staff and management with emphasis on mainframe printing; participate in mainframe systems project planning and implementation at the direction of mainframe and Network Systems management; reach out to end users to evaluate concerns relating to network availability and performance and provide technical advice and assistance to improve their computing experience; attend problem and change meetings in order to support network systems activities in these areas, and discuss open remedy tickets assigned to the network systems team; and perform special projects as assigned.
minimum_qual_requirements: (1) A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college, including or supplemented by twenty-four (24) semester credits in computer science or a related computer field and two (2) years of satisfactory full-time software experience in designing, programming, debugging, maintaining, implementing, and enhancing computer software applications, systems programming, systems analysis and design, data communication software, or database design and programming, including one year in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project; or  (2) A four-year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and six (6) years of full-time satisfactory software experience as described in â€œ1'' above, including one year in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project; or  (3) A satisfactory combination of education and experience that is equivalent to (1) or (2) above. College education may be substituted for up to two years of the required experience in (2) above on the basis that sixty (60) semester credits from an accredited college is equated to one year of experience. A masters degree in computer science or a related computer field may be substituted for one year of the required experience in (1) or (2) above. However, all candidates must have a four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent, plus at least one (1) year of satisfactory full-time software experience in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project.  NOTE: In order to have your experience accepted as Project Leader or Major Contributor experience, you must explain in detail how your experience qualifies you as a project leader or as a major contributor. business_title: CIDI Data Analyst,  Bureau of Epidemiology Services
business_title_phonetic: CIDI Data Analyst,  Bureau of Epidemiology Services
job_description: The City Research Scientist IV will be assigned to the Bureau of Epidemiology Services to work jointly with the Center for Innovation through Data Intelligence (CIDI) on specific health-related projects.     CIDI is the inter-agency data analytics and policy team for the Office of the Deputy Mayor of Health and Human Services. The mission of the Center for Innovation through Data Intelligence (CIDI) is to conduct inter-agency research to identify areas of service need in the City of New York.  CIDI collaborates with all Health and Human Service (HHS) agencies and other City partners to promote policy change that improves services for all New Yorkers.     The CIDI Analyst would work within CIDI to conduct priority health research and in doing so, support and strengthen the integration of health data and human service data.      The Data Analyst will serve as the primary project manager for mutually beneficial initiatives between DOHMH and CIDI.       Reporting to the Bureau of Epidemiology Services the Analyst duties will include but not be limited to:    -Working with CIDI to develop a joint research agenda that incorporates studies in which DOHMH data informs analyses of social service outcomes and studies in which social service data inform studies of health.    -Working with DOHMH program, IRB and legal staff to develop and operationalize appropriate governance policies around how data are used and shared with CIDI.    - For each project, developing methodology, obtaining IRB approval, compiling and preparing DOHMH data for linkage to CIDI data sources and conducting analysis of linked datasets.     - Designing and conducting analyses of DOHMH and linked datasets to support citywide planning .    - Designing and conducting analyses to describe service use and health trajectories.     - Working with DOHMH and CIDI staff to develop briefing papers, presentations, and similar materials that highlight findings from health-related research projects and analyses.     -Collaborating with other city agencies to develop and implement priority health research and analysis.    -Serving as a liaison to other Divisions within DOHMH as needed .
minimum_qual_requirements: 1.  For Assignment Level I (only physical, biological and environmental sciences and public health) A master's degree from an accredited college or university with a specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological or environmental science or in public health.  To be appointed to Assignment Level II and above, candidates must have:  1. A doctorate degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and one year of full-time experience in a responsible supervisory, administrative or research capacity in the appropriate field of specialization; or  2. A master's degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and three years of responsible full-time research experience in the appropriate field of specialization; or  3. Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have at least a master's degree in an appropriate field of specialization and at least two years of experience described in ''2'' above. business_title: Director of Program Planning,  Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control
business_title_phonetic: Director of Program Planning,  Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control
job_description: This position will report to the Director of the HIV Prevention in the Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control (BHIV). Under this leadership, the Director of Program Planning is expected to research, develop, and plan implementation of evidence-based policy and planning recommendations concerning best practices for HIV prevention programmatic implementation in New York City (NYC).     The Director will research both national and international models. She/he will assess applicability of innovative HIV prevention activities for the NYC setting and create a program plan to operationalize these activities in the context of long-term HIV prevention planning.    Specifically, tasks will include:     -- In coordination with other directors in the Prevention Program, develop new requests for proposals (RFPs) to competitively award Health Department funding to community and clinical partners citywide.  These RFPs should be completely evidence-based and developed in collaboration with senior members of the HIV Prevention team and with the Director of Business Systems.      -- Conduct comprehensive clinical and public health research of secondary sources (e.g., published and gray literature review) to identify possible new interventions for HIV prevention with applicability to the NYC environment.  Educate HIV prevention team about the findings.     -- Work across the Bureau and with the various community planning groups to create a long term, comprehensive strategic plan that will serve to maximize achievement of HIV Prevention and Care/Treatment Program goals and objectives and service delivery, using above research findings and a service gap analysis. Included in this comprehensive strategic plan will be prioritized recommendations for implementation of new HIV prevention interventions.     -- Work closely with the Care and Treatment Director of Research and Evaluation, the Deputy Director of HIV Prevention, the Director of the Epidemiology and Field Services Program and other units/programs within the Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control to obtain needed data for the planning process.    -- Assess and make recommendations concerning partnerships with community-based institutions/organizations as well as academic and other institutions for HIV prevention activities.    -- Develop and operationalize HIV prevention pilot projects.    --Based on priorities set by the Bureau and the Director of HIV Prevention, identify new grant funding, write grants, and coordinate grant submission process to increase funding for HIV Prevention program activities in NYC.     -- Lead planning of implementation of new programs in coordination with leadership from the Programs Unit, including identification of needed materials, curricula and trainings; interaction with staff/contractors involved in development of materials, curricula and trainings; and coordination with staff across the BHIV to ensure that such materials, curricula and trainings are developed in a timely and appropriate manner.       -- Work closely with the community HIV Planning Group (HPG) and other HIV-related planning groups, as needed, to collaborate on strategic plan/programming development, and to communicate planning goals, objectives and model outputs.     -- Collaborate with other DOHMH Bureaus and departments within BHIV to find synergies for HIV prevention programs.     -- Represent the DOHMH at meetings as required.    -- Supervise the Director of Risk Reduction in Vulnerable Populations.

job_description: The TLC is responsible for licensing and regulating for-hire vehicles in New York City. This includes taxis, livery cars, black cars, limousines, ambulettes, and commuter vans. Since the TLC's creation in 1971, the industries regulated by the TLC have grown to include more vehicles and drivers, and they provide more rides to the public than ever before moving over 1.25 million New Yorkers and visitors each day. TLC-regulated travel is the third largest source of public transportation in New York, after the subway and buses. On an annual basis, TLC-regulated vehicles provide transportation to 400 million people and generate over $4 billion in private revenue.    The Office of Judgment Enforcement (OJE) maintains and processes all TLC Vehicle Seizure operations, including processing all paperwork relating to vehicle release. Additionally, OJE performs all TLC collections actions, and processes all TLC license suspensions for unpaid fines and missed court hearings.    The Seizure Coordinator will be assigned to the Enforcement/USB Unit, reporting to the Deputy Director of the Office of Judgment Enforcement.  Primary duties will be to manage the TLC's 3rd-party tow pound contract, including interfacing with the pound on a daily basis in order to ensure the keeping and maintaining accurate records of all vehicles seized by TLC, including monitoring storage times and locations, and keeping an accurate count of vehicles at any drop-off or storage location at any given time.  Duties will also include interfacing with the general public daily in order to efficiently and accurately process the release of vehicles seized by the TLC.  The successful applicant may also be assigned to multiple work locations and general office duties in the Office of Judgment Enforcement, as needed, on a day-by-day basis
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. High school graduation or equivalent and six years of experience in community work or community centered activities in an area related to the duties as described above; or  3. Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have at least one year of experience as described in ''1'' above.
preferred_skills: Excellent verbal, written communication skills, and organization skills  Proficiency in all Microsoft Office Applications, especially Access, Excel, and Word  Strong project management skills  Familiarity with TLC Rules and Regulations is preferred

job_description: The Office of Chief Medical Examiner investigates cases of persons who die within New York City from criminal violence, by accident, by suicide, suddenly when in apparent health, when unattended by a physician, in a correctional facility or in any suspicious or unusual manner or where an application is made pursuant to law for a permit to cremate a body of a person.      We exist to provide answers in support of families, victims and community during times of profound need.    The core values of the OCME are to put the mission of the agency first, to be truly dedicated and to have integrity in every aspect of our professional life Under the direction of the Deputy Director of Mortuary Services, oversees the activities of the mortuaries under the auspices of the Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME); performs related work.  Typical tasks include the following:    â€¢ Visits mortuaries in the five (5) boroughs to monitor operations and resolve problems; when on site or from a central location contracts mortuary directors or other appropriate staff concerning problems requiring immediate resolution.  â€¢ Resolves issues related to the recovery, and transport of decedents, as well as case check-in /case check out, problems or issues with CMS; works with funeral directors on release of decedents to their care; works with Medicolegal Investigation staff to coordinate death scene investigations and with recovery of decedents.   â€¢ Oversees the work of mortuary staff, motor vehicle operators, and auxiliary staff; holds staff meetings as needed to discuss mortuary issues and procedures; evaluates staff performance; recommends disciplinary actions as needed.  â€¢ Monitors transportation functions and staff, including rerouting of vehicles and staff by adjusting schedules and assignments as situations arise; arranges for emergency road services for vehicles that breakdown during off hours; arranges for towing by contracted vendor; assists in the coordination of city burial transportation.  â€¢ Works with the Medical Investigator in-charge or Tour Commander to resolve assignment or case related issues city-wide, ensuring smooth and effective operations.   â€¢ Prepares reports and keeps records.  â€¢ Operates a motor vehicle.   â€¢ Performs other duties as required.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college, with specialization in criminalistics, forensic science, chemistry, biology, physics, molecular genetics, genetics, biochemistry, molecular biology, entomology, anthropology, ecology or a closely related scientific or engineering field.    2. For Assignment to Assignment Level I - B  In addition to meeting the ''Qualification Requirements For All Assignment Levels'' above, to be assigned to Assignment Level I-B individuals must have at least one year of satisfactory full-time experience in criminalistics, forensic science or analytic chemistry, or a satisfactory equivalent combination of education and experience.    3. job_description: The Division of Economic and Financial Opportunity (the Division) is committed to encouraging a competitive and diverse New York City business environment by promoting the growth and success of small businesses, with special emphasis on historically underserved groups, and ensuring their meaningful participation in the government procurement process. The Division oversees the day-to-day operations of the Cityâ€™s Minority- and Women-owned Business Enterprise (M/WBE) Program.    The Division is seeking an Executive Assistant to support the Deputy Commissioner and Division business units. In this capacity, the Executive Assistant will:    â€¢	Manage calendar and phone/e-mail correspondence for the Deputy Commissioner  â€¢	Maintain departmental contact lists, organization charts and e-mail distribution lists  â€¢	Provide clerical support, maintain files, help coordinate communication internally and externally   â€¢	Assist Division staff with day-to-day duties which includes scheduling, answering phones, and compiling prep material for meetings and events  â€¢	Handle travel arrangements and registration for the Deputy Commissioner for conferences and seminars  â€¢	Assist with special events and projects    â€¢	Arrange logistics and details associated with meetings  â€¢	Assist with updating and managing databases, producing mailings via post and digital  â€¢	Handle customer inquiries and serve as concierge, directing requests to appropriate business units and staff within the Agency  â€¢	Work on special projects as assigned    In addition, the Executive Assistant will provide specific support to the Divisionâ€™s Certification Unit. One of the Divisionâ€™s goals is to increase and retain the number of certified M/WBE companies.  Under general supervision of the Director of Certification and in collaboration with Certification Unit staff, the Executive Assistant will provide the following:     â€¢	Conduct preliminary review of applications submitted to ensure that they are complete before assignment to certification analysts for review  â€¢	Following up with applicants to encourage/guide them in completing their submissions  â€¢	Process paper and electronic applications, and related documentation, by entering and tracking submissions into database  â€¢	Work on special certification projects as needed.

business_title: City Research Scientist,  Bureau of Sexually Transmitted Disease
business_title_phonetic: City Research Scientist,  Bureau of Sexually Transmitted Disease
job_description: The mission of the BSTDC is to improve the sexual health of all New Yorkers. To achieve this, we provide direct clinical services and partner services; monitor disease trends; provide education and training to providers and community groups, conduct research and develop policies to improve sexual health and wellness. The Bureau of STD control operates 8 STD clinics throughout NYC.    As a City Research Scientist (CRS) you will be responsible for the implementation of projects with a primary focus on assurance and provider outreach activities. The CRS will report to the Director of Special Projects, Bureau of STD Control (BSTDC).    The CRS duties will include but not be limited to:    --Responsible for oversight of STD prevention and treatment activities contracted with outside providers.     --Conduct oversight, evaluation and technical assistance for 4 multi-year contracts with FQHCs and family planning providers to ensure provision of STD prevention, testing and treatment services to young men and women.    --Conduct oversight, evaluation and technical assistance for 1 multi-year contract to provide sexual health, primary care, womenâ€™s health and substance use/mental health services to the LGBT population.    --Work with external partners and other agencies to improve access and quality of STD prevention services through enhanced collaboration with primary care.    --Implementation of projects to assure the effective provision of STD programs and services in the NYC provider community.     --Adhere to all data collection and reporting requirements from local and federal funding sources.    --Run regular data reports.    --Conduct program evaluation and quality improvement projects.    --  Conduct written reports and prepare manuscripts.    --Assist in the development of BSTDC grant applications.    --Conduct program evaluation to improve the quality of STD safety net service delivery .
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A doctorate degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and one year of full-time experience in a responsible supervisory, administrative or research capacity in the appropriate field of specialization; or  2.
